Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Physics REU and RET Programs at the University of Notre Dame
Award.AbstractNarration: The Physics REU and RET programs at the University aim to provide realistic research experience to undergraduate students and high school physics teachers. The participants will work with a faculty mentor on a specific research project and will be exposed to physics research in other areas via weekly seminars, workshops, interactions with other participants, and field trips to nearby national laboratories. They will prepare a research report at the end of the program and make oral presentations at an REU-RET Symposium. They will also maintain a daily research log book and will have opportunity to participate in short courses in computer programming, electronics, machine shop, and radiation safety. A workshop will be held on Applying to Graduate Schools and Preparing for GRE's. A series of up to four workshops will be held as part of the "Ethics" component. The participants will be able to experience, and be part of, forefront research in the areas of Astronomy, Astrophysics, Biophysics, Condensed Matter Physics, High-Energy Particle Physics, and Nuclear Physics. The goal of the program is to increase, via mentoring and training, the participants's capacity to understand and do physics, and foster their potential to lead, inspire, and teach others. For most of the REU students, this will be their first exposure to how exciting physics research is, and will help them decide whether graduate education in physics is the right option for them. The primary impact is in training of the next generation of physicists who will be essential for the continued well being of our society and economy. The RET component aims at creating enthusiastic high school teachers who, in turn, will convey the excitement of physics to their students, the future physicists. This award is co-funded by the Divisions of Physics and Materials Research and by the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities in the Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Notre Dame Physics REU program is designed to provide physics majors (mostly rising seniors) from a variety of undergraduate institutions with a comprehensive view of physics research. From humble beginnings in 1985 (NSF funded since 1987), this program has progressed to an integrated and holistic approach concerned with the development of the participating students as researchers. The primary goal of the program is to provide each student with awareness, through actual hands-on research, of how physics research is done, and with an opportunity to gain confidence towards the pursuit of a physics career.

Our program lasts for 10 weeks (starting on the day after Memorial Day) and consists of participation in a research project, weekly research seminars, development of a research logbook, a research paper, two oral presentations, contact with various research groups, workshops and short courses, field trips to nearby national laboratories, and social gatherings with other members of the department. The areas available for research projects are: Astronomy and Astrophysics, Biophysics, Condensed Matter Physics, High-Energy Particle Physics, Nuclear Physics, and Physics Education research. 

The program provides each student with a realistic perspective of what graduate school and a research career might entail, including problems with equipment breakdown; designing and building new equipment; the thrill of being the first to 'see' something new; difficulties with data acquisition and analysis; interpretation of data and error analysis; writing and presenting papers; funding; and even a discussion of the current job market. Many of the students attend a machine shop course and every student becomes a more proficient computer user. Also, we offer a programming course (FORTRAN and C), which has been very beneficial to get the students involved in research more effectively.

 Over this proposal period, a total of 104 students participated in this program of which 40% were women and 18% were from under-represented minority groups. About 70% of the participants came from non-research-oriented institutions, broadly defined as those colleges where sufficient research opportunities are not generally available to undergraduate students. A total of 9 students gained international experience via participation in experiments in France, Japan, and Switzerland.

More than 80% of the participants in our program have continued on to graduate studies in Physics and other fields in science and engineering. There have been a total of 44 publications/communications and presentations at scientific and professional meetings with REU students as coauthors; including prior years, this number is ~150.

Additionally, the program has an active Research Experience for Teachers (RET) component that typically supports 12 high-schools teachers in summer research. Over an 8-week period, the teachers work with a physics mentor on a research topic of mutual interest; attend weekly REU/RET seminars; visit nearby national laboratories; and, present the results of their research at the REU/RET Symposium.

The combination of REU and RET programs, along with a University of Notre Dame supported summer research program for high school students (REHS), creates a vibrant research community involving a broad range of researchers--high school students, teachers, undergraduate students, graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and faculty members.
